message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of painless, blurry vision with halos and difficulty driving at night are consistent with cataracts, which is caused by the hardening of the lens. The absence of a red reflex also supports this diagnosis. Corneal edema would cause pain with vision loss and optic nerve head damage would cause visual field defects. Degeneration of the retina would cause progressive vision loss and distortion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of halos around lights and trouble with night driving suggest hardening of the lens, also known as cataracts. The absence of a red reflex on physical exam is also consistent with cataracts. Corneal edema, degeneration of the retina, and optic nerve head damage would present with different symptoms and physical exam findings.

We refer to articles on ophthalmology for help. The symptoms of painless, blurry vision that worsened over time with halos around lights point towards hardening of the lens, which is a common age-related change known as cataracts. The absence of a red reflex further supports this diagnosis. Corneal edema can cause blurry vision, but it is typically associated with eye pain. Degeneration of the retina and optic nerve head damage can also cause vision problems, but they would present differently compared to cataracts.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of painless, blurry vision with halos around lights and difficulty driving at night suggest hardening of the lens. Absence of a red reflex also supports the diagnosis of cataracts, which involve clouding of the eye lens.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's complaints of halos around lights and difficulty seeing at night suggest cataracts, which is a hardening of the lens. The absence of a red reflex is also characteristic of cataracts. Corneal edema usually presents with pain and redness, while degeneration of the retina and optic nerve head damage typically cause loss of visual acuity and/or field defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s blurry vision, halos around lights, and trouble driving at night indicate cataracts, which are caused by hardening of the lens. The absence of a red reflex is also a common finding in cataracts. Corneal edema can cause blurry vision but would not cause halos around lights. Degeneration of the retina and optic nerve head damage would cause different visual symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of halos and difficulty with glare, along with an absence of a red reflex, are suggestive of cataracts. Cataracts occur when the lens of the eye becomes cloudy or opaque, which can cause blurred vision, halos, and difficulty with glare.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of a red reflex and the symptoms suggest the most likely pathology is hardening of the lens, also known as cataracts. Corneal edema and optic nerve head damage do not typically cause halos or blurry vision, and degeneration of the retina is not commonly associated with loss of the red reflex.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of halos around lights and difficulty with night vision suggest the patient has cataracts, which is caused by hardening of the lens. The absence of a red reflex also supports this diagnosis. Corneal edema, degeneration of the retina, and optic nerve head damage would not cause these specific symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Absence of a red reflex, halos around lights, and trouble driving at night are classic symptoms of cataracts, which are caused by hardening of the lens. Corneal edema would cause a different type of visual distortion. Degeneration of the retina and optic nerve head damage would have different symptoms.
